title: What Do Unhealthy Betta Fish Look Like? Disease Symptoms & Treatments

steps.title: Faded or dull coloring
steps.content: Faded or dull coloring When a betta gets sick, their coloring may look faded, dull, or pale. They may even lose their color altogether. [1] X Research source Healthy betta fish have bright and vibrant coloring.

steps.title: Damaged or clamped fins
steps.content: Damaged or clamped fins According to aquarium specialist Craig Morton, an unhealthy betta may develop holes or rips in their fins. He also says their fins might appear clamped or tethered to their body—in other words, they aren't fanned out properly. [2] X Expert Source Craig Morton Aquarium Specialist, Aquarium Doctor Inc. Expert Interview. 21 July 2020. Healthy betta fish have long, damage-free fins. They gracefully fan out from their body and flow as they swim.

steps.title: Lethargy and low activity level
steps.content: Lethargy and low activity level If your betta is sick, their activity level will likely decrease; they won't be their normal, active self. Their movements may slow down and you might even catch them lying motionless on the ground. [3] X Research source Healthy betta fish are very active and curious about what you’re doing. Another sign of sickness is your fish hiding out at the bottom of the tank more often than normal. They might avoid interaction or retreat when you approach. Lethargy can be caused by other things besides sickness, like a too low or high temperature. So, make sure your providing your fish with the conditions and care they need—we discuss how best to keep your betta fish happy in the sections below!

steps.title: Decreased appetite
steps.content: Decreased appetite With some sicknesses, your betta fish may appear uninterested in food. They might even stop eating altogether. [4] X Research source Healthy betta fish are usually very eager to eat and don’t miss a meal time.

steps.title: Trouble swimming
steps.content: Trouble swimming If your betta fish is sick or unhealthy, they may swim abnormally. For instance, they might swim upside down, swim on their side, have trouble staying upright, or even sink to the bottom of the tank. [5] X Research source Healthy betta fish are active, graceful swimmers that easily stay upright and glide through the water.

steps.title: Breathing problems
steps.content: Breathing problems It may sound funny to check a fish for breathing problems. However, if your betta is constantly at the top of the tank trying to get more air or even gasping for breath, that is likely a sign of a problem. [6] X Research source Healthy betta fish naturally go to the top of the tank to take a breather at times, but doing it frequently is abnormal. According to aquarium expert Wes Corbyn, it’s normal for bettas to swim to the surface because they “have a labyrinth organ” that “allows them to breathe surface air.” [7] X Expert Source Wes Corbyn Aquarium Expert Expert Interview. 6 June 2023.

steps.title: White spots
steps.content: White spots Morton says sick betta fish sometimes develop small, white spots on their body, especially around the head and mouth, as well as a white film. [8] X Expert Source Craig Morton Aquarium Specialist, Aquarium Doctor Inc. Expert Interview. 21 July 2020. Healthy betta fish typically have clean, clear skin that’s free from spots or film. This symptom can be a sign of a certain type of parasite, called Ich. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Rubbing or scratching behaviors
steps.content: Rubbing or scratching behaviors Aquarium expert Cyriac St.Vil says if your betta tries to rub against the side of the tank or “purposely runs into objects in the tank,” they “may be showing signs of illness.” [10] X Expert Source Cyriac St.Vil Aquarium Expert Expert Interview. 7 March 2023. Similarly, if your betta is trying to scratch on plants or objects in the tank, they might also be unhealthy. [11] X Research source Healthy betta fish typically swim freely without rubbing or scratching themselves on objects in the tank.

steps.title: Cloudy, bulging eyes and other physical symptoms
steps.content: Cloudy, bulging eyes and other physical symptoms According to Morton, cloudy eyes can be a sign of illness, as healthy bettas have clear, bright eyes. [12] X Expert Source Craig Morton Aquarium Specialist, Aquarium Doctor Inc. Expert Interview. 21 July 2020. Bulging eyes can also be a sign of sickness. Watch for your betta's eyes protruding from its head. [13] X Research source More physical symptoms include : [14] X Research source Raised scales : Raised or pinecone-looking scales can be a symptom of sickness in bettas, as their scales are smooth and flat when they’re healthy. Swelling : A sick or unhealthy betta may have a swollen belly or other bulging spots on their body. Healthy bettas have smooth, bump-free skin. Gill problems : If your betta is unable to close their gills, they may be swollen, which is another sign of sickness. A healthy fish can easily open and close their gills.

steps.title: Look for deteriorating tails and fins to diagnose fin/tail rot.
steps.content: Look for deteriorating tails and fins to diagnose fin/tail rot. According to aquarium expert Marshall Stephens, the most common symptom of fin/tail rot is “deteriorated fins” or tails that have a shredded or torn appearance. He says there might also be “redness of the fins” and a “white cotton-like growth.” [15] X Expert Source Marshall Stephens Aquarium Specialist Expert Interview. 3 January 2023. Also, look for darker coloring near the end of the tail. Be aware that some longer-tailed varieties, such as halfmoon bettas, may try to bite their fins because they are too heavy. In this case, look for other symptoms of sickness as well as torn fins.

steps.title: Watch for white patches to diagnose a fungal infection.
steps.content: Watch for white patches to diagnose a fungal infection . Stephens says the most common symptoms of a fungal infection are “cotton-like growths around the mouth and fins.” He says you might also notice “red streaks in the fins.” [16] X Expert Source Marshall Stephens Aquarium Specialist Expert Interview. 3 January 2023. Your fish might also have clumpy fins or be less active than normal. [17] X Research source While a fungal infection is different from fin/tail rot, they are treated in much the same way.

steps.title: Change the water to treat your fish.
steps.content: Change the water to treat your fish. If you suspect your fish has an infection, Morton says the first step is to change out the water . [18] X Expert Source Craig Morton Aquarium Specialist, Aquarium Doctor Inc. Expert Interview. 21 July 2020. Of course, you need to remove your fish and put it in a holding container while doing so. Fin/tail rot and fungal infections often develop from dirty water, so you need to provide a clean environment for your fish. Also clean the tank before putting fresh water back in. [19] X Research source To remove the water in the tank, Morton suggests you use a hose to siphon out the dirty water. [20] X Expert Source Craig Morton Aquarium Specialist, Aquarium Doctor Inc. Expert Interview. 21 July 2020. Remove the decorations and gravel. St.Vil suggests soaking them in “1 part water and 3 parts vinegar” for 1 hour. Then, rinse them off thoroughly. [21] X Expert Source Cyriac St.Vil Aquarium Expert Expert Interview. 7 March 2023. For any rocks, bake them at 450 °F (232 °C) for 1 hour. Let them cool before adding them back to the tank. Clean out the tank with bleach and water. St.Vil recommends a solution of “1 part bleach and 5 parts water.” Then, rinse out the tank several times. [22] X Expert Source Cyriac St.Vil Aquarium Expert Expert Interview. 7 March 2023. Fill the tank with fresh water and add a water conditioner . Allow your fish to acclimate to the water before directly putting them back in the tank.

steps.title: Add a medication into the water.
steps.content: Add a medication into the water. To treat fin/tail rot , Morton suggests adding API BettaFix medication to the water. [23] X Expert Source Craig Morton Aquarium Specialist, Aquarium Doctor Inc. Expert Interview. 21 July 2020. You can also give your betta ampicillin or tetracycline, which you add to the water. How much you add depends on the size of the tank—simply follow the directions on the package. [24] X Research source If your betta just has a fungal infection , they won't need tetracycline or ampicillin. Instead, add a fungus eliminator to the water. This helps keep the fungus out of the water.

steps.title: Repeatedly change the water and add medication.
steps.content: Repeatedly change the water and add medication. Change the water at least every 3 days. Every time you change the water, add the medication back in. Only stop when your betta fish’s fins or tail seem to be growing back in, which can take up to a month. [25] X Research source For fungal infections , look for the white patches and other symptoms to disappear. When they do, treat the tank with BettaFix to help eliminate the fungus.

steps.title: Look for a gold or rust-colored sheen on your fish.
steps.content: Look for a gold or rust-colored sheen on your fish. One of the best ways to diagnose velvet is to shine a flashlight directly on your fish. This will help you see the shimmer of gold or rust that this disease can produce on the scales. Your fish might exhibit other symptoms, such as lethargy, loss of appetite, clamped fins, and rubbing or scratching themselves against walls or items in the aquarium. [26] X Research source Velvet is a parasitic infection. This parasite can be prevented by adding aquarium salt and water conditioner to your tank on a regular basis. [27] X Research source Add 1 tsp (6 g) of aquarium salt for every 2 ½ gallons (9 L) of water. You also need 1 drop of water conditioner per 1 gallon (3.8 L), though always read the instructions that come with your water conditioner. Only add extra salt when doing water changes, not when topping off a tank. [28] X Research source

steps.title: Separate the sick fish and use BettaFix to treat velvet.
steps.content: Separate the sick fish and use BettaFix to treat velvet. If your betta is in an aquarium with other fish, place your fish in a separate tank. Then, follow the directions on the bottle of BettaFix to add the correct amount to your fish’s water. [29] X Research source Alternatively, use a medication like Seachem Cupramine , Methylene Blue , or Maracide . Continue adding medicine until your fish no longer exhibits symptoms of velvet. Simply check the medication’s packaging to see how often to add it to the tank.

steps.title: Treat the whole tank with BettaFix to prevent velvet from spreading.
steps.content: Treat the whole tank with BettaFix to prevent velvet from spreading. If your betta lives with other fish, it’s a good idea to treat the entire tank for velvet. Velvet is a very contagious disease, so it could have spread to your other fish. Simply follow the directions on the bottle of BettaFix to add the correct amount to the community tank. [30] X Research source

steps.title: Look for white spots all over the body that look like salt.
steps.content: Look for white spots all over the body that look like salt. Ich is a parasite that produces small, white spots on your fish’s body, says St.Vil. [31] X Expert Source Cyriac St.Vil Aquarium Expert Expert Interview. 7 March 2023. Also, look for clamped fins and lethargy. Your fish may also stop eating. [32] X Research source Like velvet, this parasite is preventable if you treat the water right. St.Vil suggests doing “regular water changes and regular filter media changes” to prevent ich. [33] X Expert Source Cyriac St.Vil Aquarium Expert Expert Interview. 7 March 2023. Regularly adding aquarium salt or water conditioner to your tank can also help prevent ich. Always read the directions on the product to add the correct amount into your tank.

steps.title: Raise the temperature to treat ich in large tanks.
steps.content: Raise the temperature to treat ich in large tanks. If you have a large community tank over 5 gallons (19 L), raising the temperature to 85°F (29°C) can kill off the parasite. Just don't do this if your tank is smaller, as increasing the temperature can overheat the tank and kill your fish. [34] X Research source

steps.title: Clean the tank
steps.content: Clean the tank and change the water. Ich thrives in dirty water, so it’s important to clean the water and tank. Siphon out the dirty water, disinfect the tank and decorations, and add in fresh, conditioned water. To help ensure the parasite is gone, heat the water to 85°F (29°C) before putting the fish back in the tank. [35] X Research source Be sure to treat the new water with water conditioner or aquarium salt before returning your fish to the tank. This helps keep the tank from reintroducing the parasite.

steps.title: Add an ich medication to the water, like Tetra Ick Guard.
steps.content: Add an ich medication to the water, like Tetra Ick Guard . Ich medications kill off the parasite and help prevent other infections from forming. Simply follow the directions on the medication for the proper dosage and how often to add it. Some other common medications include API Super Ick Cure and Kordon Ich Attack . [36] X Research source BettaFix can also be used in a pinch.

steps.title: Look for bulging eyes to diagnose popeye.
steps.content: Look for bulging eyes to diagnose popeye. Blake says “popeye is a symptom of a bacterial infection.” He says “when a fish becomes infected with bacteria in the eye,” oftentimes “the buildup of gas from the bacteria…results in the eye popping out.” So, look for either of your fish’s eyes to bulge or protrude from their head. [37] X Research source Blake notes that fish often develop popeye due to a weakened immune system, which might be “because of dirty tank water or improper water conditions,” like too cool or hot water. [38] X Expert Source Brian Blake Aquarium Expert Expert Interview. 25 January 2024. Popeye can sometimes be a symptom of other diseases, such as tuberculosis. Unfortunately, there is no cure for betta fish tuberculosis. [39] X Research source

steps.title: Clean the tank and change the water.
steps.content: Clean the tank and change the water. To treat popeye , siphon out the dirty water and sanitize the tank, decorations, and gravel. Then, add conditioner to some fresh water and pour it into the clean tank. [40] X Research source Continue to change out the water every 3 days until you notice your fish getting better.

steps.title: Add ampicillin into the water.
steps.content: Add ampicillin into the water. Ampicillin helps treat popeye that’s caused by bacterial infections. Simply add this medication to the water every time you change the water—simply follow the directions on the bottle for how much to add. [41] X Research source Continue this regimen for 1 week after you stop seeing signs of the problem.

steps.title: Look for swelling and raised scales to diagnose dropsy.
steps.content: Look for swelling and raised scales to diagnose dropsy. Dropsy is typically caused by an infection in your fish’s abdominal organs, which causes their belly to swell and bulge. This disease can also cause your fish’s scales to stick out, giving them the appearance of a pinecone. [42] X Research source

steps.title: Isolate your fish and add Epsom salt into the tank.
steps.content: Isolate your fish and add Epsom salt into the tank. Place your fish in a separate tank if they’re in a shared aquarium. Then, Morton recommends adding “2.5 teaspoons (12.5 g) of Epsom salt” for every “ten gallons (37.8 L)” of water in the tank to help cure dropsy. [43] X Expert Source Craig Morton Aquarium Specialist, Aquarium Doctor Inc. Expert Interview. 21 July 2020. Change the water every few days and add more salt until your fish starts to recover.

steps.title: Feed your fish antibacterial fish food.
steps.content: Feed your fish antibacterial fish food. Morton also recommends feeding your fish antibacterial fish food to help cure dropsy. Replacing their regular food with food containing antibiotics can help kill off the bacterial or parasitic infection causing dropsy. [44] X Expert Source Craig Morton Aquarium Specialist, Aquarium Doctor Inc. Expert Interview. 21 July 2020.

steps.title: Look for sinking or an inability to swim to diagnose swim bladder.
steps.content: Look for sinking or an inability to swim to diagnose swim bladder. Swim bladder disease affects your betta fish’s swim bladder organ, which helps them float and swim properly. So, if they have this disease, you might notice them having trouble swimming upright, floating upside down, or sinking to the bottom of the tank. [45] X Research source

steps.title: Reduce feeding.
steps.content: Reduce feeding. Swim bladder disease is often caused by overfeeding. If your fish is eating normally (not refusing to eat or acting disinterested in food), skip feeding them for 1 day. This can help their digestive system reset and reduce the swelling causing swim bladder disease. [46] X Research source

steps.title: Change the water and add salt.
steps.content: Change the water and add salt. Swim bladder disease can also be caused by a bacterial infection. So, it’s a good idea to siphon out the dirty water, clean the tank and decorations, and add in fresh, conditioned water. Morton also recommends adding “2 teaspoons (12 g) of non-iodized salt” and 2 teaspoons (12 g) of “Epsom salt per gallon (3.8 L) to the aquarium.” [47] X Expert Source Craig Morton Aquarium Specialist, Aquarium Doctor Inc. Expert Interview. 21 July 2020. If your betta fish is in a communal tank, place them in a separate tank for treatment.

steps.title: Look for holes or pits around your fish’s head.
steps.content: Look for holes or pits around your fish’s head. Hole in the head disease results in holes and pits around your fish’s head and eyes. It can also cause your fish’s flesh to erode away. You might also notice your fish acting lethargic. [48] X Research source

steps.title: Change and treat the water.
steps.content: Change and treat the water. Hole in the head can be caused by many things, but it's often due to a bacterial infection. So, siphon out the dirty water and replace it with fresh, conditioned water. Then, treat the water with a general medication that kills off bacteria and parasites, like API General Cure . [49] X Research source

steps.title: Feed your fish
steps.content: Feed your fish high-quality food. Hole in the head can also be caused by nutritional deficiencies. Ensure your fish is getting all the vitamins and nutrients they need by giving them high quality betta fish pellets . [50] X Research source

steps.title: Look for signs of swelling.
steps.content: Look for signs of swelling. If your betta fish suddenly swells, they may be constipated. It’s important to treat this problem soon. [51] X Research source Note: Constipation can look similar to swim bladder disease. If treating them for constipation does not help, follow the methods for curing swim bladder disease.

steps.title: Stop feeding your fish for 1 whole day.
steps.content: Stop feeding your fish for 1 whole day. The best way to help constipation is to stop your fish’s regular diet for 1 day. This will give them time to digest and move food through their system. [52] X Research source

steps.title: Feed your fish live food after fasting them.
steps.content: Feed your fish live food after fasting them. For instance, feed your betta brine shrimp or blood worms. [53] X Research source According to Stephens, the general rule on how much food to give tropical fish, like bettas, is “not more than they can eat in about 30 seconds.” Make sure you feed your fish about twice per day. [54] X Expert Source Marshall Stephens Aquarium Specialist Expert Interview. 3 January 2023. Another great option is to feed your betta fish peas, as they contain fiber that can reduce constipation. Simply cut a few peas into tiny pieces.

steps.title: Don't feed your fish as much.
steps.content: Don't feed your fish as much. Constipation is generally a sign you are feeding your betta too much food. Therefore, once they start eating normally again, you need to feed them less than you were. [55] X Research source

steps.title: Change the water weekly.
steps.content: Change the water weekly. To keep your betta fish happy and healthy , Morton says to “change 20-25% of the water every week.” This helps ensure that the water stays clean and free from bacteria, parasites, and fungi that cause diseases. [56] X Expert Source Craig Morton Aquarium Specialist, Aquarium Doctor Inc. Expert Interview. 21 July 2020.

steps.title: Keep the water warm, around 76-82°F (24-28°C).
steps.content: Keep the water warm, around 76-82°F (24-28°C). Bettas are tropical, warm-water fish that thrive in temperatures between 76-82°F (24-28°C). To ensure your betta fish stays warm, Morton recommends adding an aquarium heater to your tank to keep the water temperature consistent. [57] X Expert Source Craig Morton Aquarium Specialist, Aquarium Doctor Inc. Expert Interview. 21 July 2020. Exposure to cooler temperatures can stress your betta fish out and weaken their immune system, making them more vulnerable to diseases.

steps.title: Add a filter to your tank if you don’t have one.
steps.content: Add a filter to your tank if you don’t have one. Because betta fish have a labyrinth organ that allows them to breathe air, they can technically live in a tank without a filter. However, Corbyn says betta fish tend to “live healthier, longer lives in a tank with a filter.” Simply add a small filter with a gentle flow to keep the tank nicely oxygenated. [58] X Expert Source Wes Corbyn Aquarium Expert Expert Interview. 6 June 2023.

steps.title: Give your betta fish high-quality food.
steps.content: Give your betta fish high-quality food. Ensure your betta fish gets the nutrients they need by feeding them high-quality betta fish pellets. For instance, Morton suggests brands like Hikari Betta Bio-Gold , Tetra BettaMin , and API Betta Food . [59] X Expert Source Craig Morton Aquarium Specialist, Aquarium Doctor Inc. Expert Interview. 21 July 2020. Feed your betta fish twice per day, once in the morning and once in the evening. Make sure you don’t overfeed your fish, as this can cause them to get ill. Morton says to remember that “the size of the fish’s eye is the size of the stomach.” [60] X Expert Source Craig Morton Aquarium Specialist, Aquarium Doctor Inc. Expert Interview. 21 July 2020.

steps.title: Decorate your fish’s tank and keep it in a calm location.
steps.content: Decorate your fish’s tank and keep it in a calm location. Constant stress can also harm your betta fish, so ensure their tank is set up to their liking. Corbyn recommends adding “a few live plants with a small light” to the tank to create a natural environment and give your fish a place to hide and rest. [61] X Expert Source Wes Corbyn Aquarium Expert Expert Interview. 6 June 2023. If your fish seems stressed, St.Vil suggests removing distractions, like mirrors, from around the tank and ensuring the space is free from light or noise disruptions. [62] X Expert Source Cyriac St.Vil Aquarium Expert Expert Interview. 7 March 2023.
